snippet: If control of the Senate is not settled on Tuesday, strategists foresee a frenzy that would make a runoff look like Iowa during a presidential campaign.
abstract: Democrats and Republicans are preparing for likely runoff elections in Georgia and Louisiana, and chance that control of the Senate will not be determined until 2015; in Georgia, Republican David Perdue and Democrat Michelle Nunn are running neck and neck, with Libertarian Amanda Swafford garnering only few percentage points in polls; Louisiana's election is a so-called jungle primary, unusual non partisan race in which all candidates are on same ballot, regardless of party.

byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and SHERYL GAY STOLBERG
byline.contributor:
Alan Blinder contributed reporting
from Morrow, Ga., and Katy
Reckdahl from Abita Springs, La.

lead_paragraph: If control of the Senate is not settled on Tuesday, strategists foresee a frenzy that would make a runoff look like Iowa during a presidential campaign.

headline.main: Senate Control May Be Decided by Runoff Votes in Louisiana and Georgia
headline.print_headline: Senate Control May Be Decided by Runoff Votes
